awd_titl_txt: Examining Faculty Attitudes and Strategies that Support Successful Flipped Teaching
awd_abstract_narration:
Flipped teaching is an educational approach that shifts lectures from class time to out of class, by using other formats such as online video. This change frees up class time for students to deepen their understanding through activities such as team problem-solving, working with real-world data, and group discussions. Despite growing evidence that active learning in flipped classrooms can increase student learning and motivation, some faculty members have resisted this approach.  The resistance is due in part to lack of awareness about how to flip a course and concerns about having enough time to prepare effective course materials. This project will help address barriers to using a flipped class format by supporting cohorts of faculty at Southern Illinois University at Edwardsville and St. Louis Community College to develop and implement new flipped courses across multiple STEM departments. Results obtained from research on project activities will provide information about what is needed for broad implementation of flipped courses, across different STEM departments, and at different types of institutions. Successful implementation of flipped teaching by 24 faculty members over the three years of the project is expected to improve retention and success in STEM, including retention of students who are from historically underrepresented groups. 

Through rigorous research, the project will examine faculty perceptions, attitudes, and intentions about flipping their classrooms. The project's three overarching research goals are: 1) How do faculty perceive and implement flipped teaching? 2)  How does faculty implementation of flipped teaching at a four-year master's university compare with faculty implementation at a two-year community college? and, 3) What are the essential design principles for implementing a successful flipped classroom at each type of institution? Six faculty from the community college and six from the university will receive professional development in flipped teaching and create pre-class assignments, in-class activities, and learning assessments. The professional development is expected to increase faculty confidence and skills in flipped teaching, enabling them to serve as mentors to other faculty in the future. A robust set of quantitative and qualitative data derived from surveys and interviews will enable the project team to determine faculty decision-making during course redesign and their perceptions of implementing the new teaching model, identify factors that support and hinder implementation of flipped teaching, and explore which factors are common to both institutions and which are specific to institutional type. The research team will use descriptive and inferential statistics to analyze pre/post surveys and thematic coding techniques to examine data from the interview transcripts. Additionally, the team will examine student grades and course completion rates, as well as student perceptions of the flipped teaching experience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Examining Faculty Attitudes and Strategies that Support Successful Flipped Teaching (Abstract # 1821664)

The project examined elements associated with the successful implementation of flipped teaching at the faculty level and developed an implementation model. This project aimed to increase faculty knowledge, skills, positive attitudes, and intentions to use flipped instruction in their future courses. We examined provisions and barriers at the individual, departmental, and institutional levels by testing flipped teaching in 122 STEM classrooms of 24 faculty members across two distinct types of institutions. Twelve faculty members from Southern Illinois University Edwardsville (SIUE), a public masters-level university, and twelve from a two-year community college with four campuses, St. Louis Community College (STLCC), aimed to create robust and effective flipped learning environments. Through analysis of the survey, interview, and course implementation data, it was evident that participants prepared appropriate pre- and in-class assignments and assessments and successfully implemented flipped teaching in their classrooms. With the benefit of first-hand knowledge, cohort 1 served as cohort 2's peer mentor as cohort 2 implemented flipped instruction in their courses. Many faculty participants revealed in their interviews that the peer support network and ongoing support were critical to the continuing design and implementation of flipped teaching. 

Additional research questions were posed as circumstances changed and opportunities existed. One such question was whether the participants could adapt to remote flipped teaching during the shutdown of institutions due to COVID. This project exemplified that flipped instruction could be effectively adapted to online education while preserving aspects of active learning. During Year 4 (no-cost extension), the study helped examine the return from remote to in-person format as institutions reopened. 

Our results suggest that successful flipped teaching implementation requires an adjustment period allowing perceived barriers to decrease after repeated implementations. Knowledge for both cohorts increased, and self-efficacy for cohort 2 increased over time. Towards the second half of Year 2, when COVID-19 forced closures of educational institutions, participants found their flipped teaching resources beneficial while transitioning to online instruction. In the first semester of Year 3, cohort 2's less positive perception was towards scheduling and timing issues, whereas during the second semester, it was related to students' attitudes (e.g., lack of motivation and participation). Over half of the participants continued to participate in the study during Year 4 when it was optional. Data from Year 4 showed overall success with flipped teaching (e.g., students more engaged and more positive attitudes towards flipped instruction). Cumulative data suggested that non-white male students at the community college were more optimistic about flipped teaching than other student groups.

In the exit survey, participants agreed that they gained knowledge to successfully implement flipped instruction, which worked better for some students. Participants expressed a favorable attitude toward using flipped teaching with undergraduate students. Ninety-two percent of the participants reported that they intended to continue using flipped teaching in at least one of their courses. They perceived flipped teaching as a practical, engaging teaching strategy and believed that their students could connect the classroom content with the real world. 

The stakeholder survey results showed that ninety-five percent of the stakeholders (n=12) perceived the flipped teaching model as acceptable; it strengthened the teacher-student relationship and was more engaging and productive than traditional approaches. Factors that influenced the continuous adoption of flipped teaching were related to student buy-in, released time, and faculty development to support flipped teaching in their departments. 

Approximately 150 members attended the IFLIP symposium in Year 4, among which 68 attendees completed an exit survey. After attending the symposium, more than 90% of the attendees reportedly planned to implement flipped instructions in their future courses using new information learned from the symposium and indicated that they were either very likely or likely to recommend flipped teaching to their colleagues. 

Dissemination efforts have yielded a book chapter, an editorial, nine peer-reviewed publications, 23 conference posters or podium presentations, and seven workshops. Materials developed and implemented are stored in the SIUE STEM Center's website repository and available to the public (http://www.siuestemcenter.org/iflip-research).

The broader impact of this project was to employ an evidence-based pedagogic approach to positively impact student outcomes while pairing a community college and a four-year public university. STEM faculty from different disciplines at the two institutions worked together and learned from each other. The design choice of two cohorts, with the first cohort mentoring the second cohort, allowed interesting comparisons of the impact of professional development on faculty and student success. A strong learning community was formed among the participants, who provided ongoing support to the members and long-term collaborations and friendships. This study exemplifying a process from design to implementation provides an evidence-based model for transforming STEM teaching and learning.
